thread.title: Cameron focuses on security

title: Cameron focuses on security
text:
Cameron focuses on national and economic security Jim Pickard, Chief Political Correspondent ©PA 
David Cameron has signalled extra spending on the SAS and a doubling in the number of British drones as he tries to push ahead with a parliamentary vote on air strikes against jihadis in Syria . 
The prime minister pleaded with President Putin to “change direction” and join other nations in attacking Isis in Syria after the Russians struck anti-Assad rebels this week. “They are backing the butcher Assad which is a terrible mistake by them for the world,” he said on the BBC’s Andrew Marr Show . More Sheffield agrees £900m devolution deal 
Mr Cameron was speaking ahead of the first Tory party conference since the party’s emphatic victory in May’s general election. 
The Tory leader intends to make security the key issue of the four-day event, exploiting Labour’s divisions over the Trident nuclear deterrent. “We will provide security at every stage in your life,” he said. 
The Tories have claimed repeatedly that Jeremy Corbyn’s leadership of Labour poses a threat to Britain’s national and economic security. 
Labour’s new leader has said that he could not think of any circumstances where he would authorise military action — and he has insisted he would never use nuclear weapons as prime minister . 
Mr Corbyn last week said Mr Cameron had undermined the security of millions of families with his cuts to the welfare state. 
The prime minister insisted on Sunday that cuts to in-work tax credits would go ahead in the new year despite criticism from fellow Tories including David Willetts, a former Conservative minister who now chairs the Resolution Foundation think-tank. 
The changes were part of reforms that would leave people better off — including a higher minimum wage — said Mr Cameron. 
He also unveiled plans for a new GP contract to help deliver seven-day services for all patients by 2020. There would also be seven-day hospital services across half the country by 2018, he promised. 
Despite attempts to focus on other issues, the Tory conference is already being overshadowed by splits over Europe in the run-up to the EU referendum, as well as speculation about the contest to succeed Mr Cameron in a few years’ time. 
With their first majority in the House of Commons for nearly two decades, many Tories are agitating for Mr Cameron to flex his muscles harder against Brussels. 
At the same time there are jitters within the “In” side of the referendum campaign about Mr Cameron’s apparent ambivalence about EU membership. 
On Sunday the prime minister said Britain needed access to the single market and to have a “say over the rules” governing it. 
But he added that he would only campaign to stay in Europe if his renegotiation was a success. “I have always said that if I don’t get what I want I’m ruling nothing out,” he said. “I am fighting for these things, and I can’t guarantee I will get them.” 
Mr Cameron is expected to use his speech on Wednesday to argue that Britain is better off within the EU single market but outside the euro and the Schengen free-movement area — but only as long as the renegotiation is a success. 
“We need Europe to be an answer to our competitiveness, not a threat to it,” he told the BBC. 
Europhile corporations have been advised by Downing Street to stay out of the debate until the renegotiation is complete. 
Meanwhile, the head of GE, the industrial giant — which employs 17,000 in the UK — said he was relaxed about whether the UK stayed in the EU. 
“As a global investor, it really doesn’t matter,” Jeff Immelt told the Sunday Telegraph. “It’s important that the UK has good relationships around the world, but I don’t really think that its place in the European Union makes that much difference.” 
Tory MPs are likely to be incensed this week if the European Court of Justice on Tuesday forces Britain to give prisoners the right to vote in European elections — an idea Mr Cameron has described as “sickening”. 
George Osborne gave a wide-ranging interview to the Mail on Sunday where he disclosed his one-time love of NWA, the hip-hop group and how he met his wife. 
The interview is likely to be seen as part of an attempt by the chancellor to broaden his image in readiness for a leadership bid. 
Mr Cameron has suggested that he will step down well ahead of the 2020 general election. 
While Mr Osborne is currently the bookmakers’ favourite, Mr Cameron said he was open-minded about his successor. “It is not up to me,” he told the BBC. “Sometimes the outsider wins.” 
According to the Sunday Times, some 18 ministers and former ministers have discussed the prospect of running. 
They include familiar names such as Boris Johnson, Theresa May and Sajid Javid — but also newer MPs including Dominic Raab, Penny Mordaunt and Andrea Leadsom. Nicky Morgan, education secretary, said last week that she was likely to stand in the contest. 
Mr Johnson is expected to tell the conference in Manchester that he has proved that he can beat the left in London in two mayoral elections. He will contrast his “one nation” belief in economic and social progress with Mr Corbyn’s “class war” rhetoric. 
Tens of thousands of leftwing activists are expected to gather in Manchester today to protest outside the conference centre against Conservative spending cuts. Related Topics
